user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_close_:
```c
static int lfs_file_close_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
#ifndef LFS_READONLY
    int err = lfs_file_sync_(lfs, file);
#else
    int err = 0;
#endif

    // remove from list of mdirs
    lfs_mlist_remove(lfs, (struct lfs_mlist*)file);

    // clean up memory
    if (!file->cfg->buffer) {
        lfs_free(file->cache.buffer);
    }

    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function lfs_file_close_:
typedef struct lfs_file {
    struct lfs_file *next;
    uint16_t id;
    uint8_t type;
    lfs_mdir_t m;

    struct lfs_ctz {
        lfs_block_t head;
        lfs_size_t size;
    } ctz;

    uint32_t flags;
    lfs_off_t pos;
    lfs_block_t block;
    lfs_off_t off;
    lfs_cache_t cache;

    const struct lfs_file_config *cfg;
} lfs_file_t
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
int err = 0;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment "int err = 0;" appears inside the #else branch of a preprocessor conditional. When LFS_READONLY is defined this line is compiled and executed (its value is returned later), so it is reachable. When LFS_READONLY is not defined the line is not part of the translation unit (preprocessed away), which is not considered unreachable code in the sense of Rule 2.1. Therefore there is no MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 violation.
